src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/160865iB94DEE269BA59D6C/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"episode-63-spdevweekly.png\" alt=\"episode-63-spdevweekly.png\" /></span></P>\n<P><SPAN>In addition to drawing attention to the latest advancements being delivered by the SharePoint Community and Microsoft, Vesa and Waldek’s discussion this week focused on: The continued necessity for code analysis –</SPAN><WBR /><SPAN>&nbsp;server-side and browser-side. Fortunately, the job is made easier with the great contributions being delivered by the SPFx community that help drive solid coding projects. Thank you. In the coming week there are more events, fine tuning 1.10 release, CLI updates, and work on Fluid Framework capabilities sure to save users many hours of time.</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>This episode was recorded on Monday, December 9, 2019.</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><SPAN><A href=\"https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/sharepoint/blogs/sharepoint-dev-weekly-episode-63/\" target=\"_self\">SharePoint Dev Weekly - Episode 63</A>&nbsp;- at SharePoint Dev Blog</SPAN></LI>\n</UL>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 10 Dec 2019 13:30:46 +0000","feedId":13333,"bgimg":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/160865iB94DEE269BA59D6C/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999","linkMd5":"72272987ef22d42ccee0cacf0899435a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-31-32-643_68581be1478cf0cf.webp","destWidth":998,"destHeight":562,"sourceBytes":314540,"destBytes":42374,"author":"Vesa Juvonen","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/160865iB94DEE269BA59D6C/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn85@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-31-32-643_68581be1478cf0cf.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598322688842},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","title":"Build a crisis management site to connect people and information","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/build-a-crisis-management-site-to-connect-people-and-information/ba-p/1216791","description":"<P>Change agents, from virus outbreaks like COVID-19 to unexpected weather emergencies, highlight the importance of establishing and keeping open the lines of communication. The goal: to ensure everyone stays briefed on the situation and any business impacts.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>To address crises, meetings move online, daily guidance email updates get sent, and dedicated sites emerge to consolidate news, related resources and topical Q&amp;A.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>This ‘how to’ post addresses the latter, to guide you through simple steps and configuration to establish a <EM>crisis management</EM> site based on a SharePoint communication site. You, too, will also find additional links to helpful guides and videos at the end.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_001_Contoso-crisis-management-site-complete.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175876i1C97FD49B42B3F7E/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_001_Contoso-crisis-management-site-complete.jpg\" alt=\"“Crisis Management” SharePoint communication site with top navigation and seven web parts laid out to provide access to people and information from inside and outside the organization.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">“Crisis Management” SharePoint communication site with top navigation and seven web parts laid out to provide access to people and information from inside and outside the organization.</span></span></P>\n<P><FONT size=\"4\">Note: tenant admins can provision a pre-configured crisis management site using this new look book design: \"<STRONG><A href=\"https://lookbook.microsoft.com/details/8f8337d2-b1f6-4a84-91a4-9081f841f0f6\" target=\"_self\">Crisis Communications - announcements, news, resources, communities and calls-to-action</A></STRONG>.\" Kudos and thanks to&nbsp;<LI-USER uid=\"206589\"></LI-USER>&nbsp;&amp;&nbsp;<LI-USER uid=\"369\"></LI-USER>.&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>How to create a crisis management site</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>Beyond reading this blog, getting from concept to live site should take no more than two hours. And before you commit to a single pixel, we suggest you take a few minutes to draft a wireframe of the site to identify desired content and information placement; this is what you see as #1 in the below four-image graphic; this, too, will start to describe what <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/using-web-parts-on-sharepoint-pages-336e8e92-3e2d-4298-ae01-d404bbe751e0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SharePoint web parts</A> you will need.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Back of the napkin, check. Let’s get to it.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT color=\"#339966\"><STRONG>Create the site</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<OL>\n<LI>Go to your <U>SharePoint start page</U>\n<UL>\n<LI>Note: Use this common URL pattern to go right to it, or click the SharePoint tile within the Office 365 app launcher (aka, the waffle in the upper left of Office 365 user interface): <U>https://[yourcompany].sharepoint.com/_layouts/15/sharepoint.aspx</U>&nbsp;</LI>\n</UL>\n</LI>\n<LI>Click <STRONG>+ Create site</STRONG></LI>\n<LI>Choose <STRONG>Communication site </STRONG>[Support article: \"<A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/Create-a-communication-site-in-SharePoint-Online-7FB44B20-A72F-4D2C-9173-FC8F59BA50EB\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Create a communication site in SharePoint Online</A>\"]\n<UL>\n<LI>Note: This is what you see as #2 in the below four-image graphic.</LI>\n</UL>\n</LI>\n<LI>Choose the <STRONG>Topic</STRONG> design, enter site name, and click <STRONG>Finish</STRONG>.\n<UL>\n<LI>Note: You’ll then see your new communication site with placeholder content. This is what you see as #3 in the below four-image graphic.</LI>\n</UL>\n</LI>\n</OL>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_002_creation-steps.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175877i1C94A866C0FE88D5/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_002_creation-steps.jpg\" alt=\"Create the SharePoint communication site in four steps: 1) draw wire frame content layout plan, 2) create the site from SharePoint start page, 3) edit and rearrange text, words, links, sections, layouts off of template, and 4) finalize design, content and permissions.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Create the SharePoint communication site in four steps: 1) draw wire frame content layout plan, 2) create the site from SharePoint start page, 3) edit and rearrange text, words, links, sections, layouts off of template, and 4) finalize design, content and permissions.</span></span></P>\n<P>Note: if you are unable to create sites within your Office 365 tenant, send a request to your SharePoint admin to create the site and assign you as a site owner. Once created and assigned, you can move to the next steps described in this post.</P>\n<P><STRONG>&nbsp;</STRONG></P>\n<P><FONT color=\"#339966\"><STRONG>Adjust section layouts and add useful web parts</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>From here, it’s all about actualizing your wire frame; if it has a coffee stain on it by now – that just adds character. It’s now time to add sections, select useful web parts and content layout.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>On the new crisis management site, click the highlighted <STRONG>Edit</STRONG> button. Hover your mouse below the title area and you'll see a “+” appear: this applies to both section layouts (the “+” sign appears when hovering near the left side of the page) and when adding web parts (the “+” sign appears more in the middle of the page, and then under each added web part).</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_003_section-layouts.jpg\" style=\"width: 496px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175878iB591807F655D705C/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_003_section-layouts.jpg\" alt=\"Hover near the left side of the page makes the &quot;+&quot; sign appear to add section layouts.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Hover near the left side of the page makes the \"+\" sign appear to add section layouts.</span></span></P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_004_web-parts.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175879i26E2BA1771DA72E1/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_004_web-parts.jpg\" alt=\"Hover more in the center of the page to make the &quot;+&quot; sign appear to add web parts.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Hover more in the center of the page to make the \"+\" sign appear to add web parts.</span></span></P>\n<P>Click&nbsp;<STRONG>+</STRONG>&nbsp;to add content like text, documents, video and more; learn more about how to <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/using-web-parts-on-sharepoint-pages-336e8e92-3e2d-4298-ae01-d404bbe751e0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">find and use web parts</A> &amp; <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/add-sections-and-columns-on-a-sharepoint-modern-page-fc491eb4-f733-4825-8fe2-e1ed80bd0899\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">add sections and columns</A>.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Now, make the site useful and actionable.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT color=\"#339966\"><STRONG>Add your content, and update it any time</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>In the above example crisis management site (first larger graphic in this post and #4 in the above four-image graphic), it uses top navigation (mega menu), a two-column section above a single column section – all to the left of a vertically laid out section, and a total of seven web parts.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Going left-to-right, top-down, the crisis management site uses the following web parts:</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-hero-web-part-d57f449b-19a0-4b0d-8ce3-be5866430645\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Hero</A> – use this to highlight the most important, or newest, content on the site. The one in the example uses the carousel layout.</LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/add-text-and-tables-to-your-page-with-the-text-web-part-729c0aa1-bc0d-41e3-9cde-c60533f2c801\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Text</A> – use the rich-text editor to add and update the main intent of the site, or an important message. You can use and adjust color, font size, hyperlink and tables. &nbsp;</LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-quick-links-web-part-e1df7561-209d-4362-96d4-469f85ab2a82\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Quick links</A> – call out primary resources. These can be internal sites, pages, documents, videos, FAQs, and can be external links, too.</LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-a-yammer-web-part-in-sharepoint-online-a53cfa0c-3d09-42c8-a286-1038a81c59da#conversations\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Yammer Conversations</A> – create an associated “Crisis Management” community and take questions and manage feedback directly from the site.\n<UL>\n<LI>Recent, related blog: “<A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/yammer-blog/keeping-employees-informed-and-engaged-during-difficult-times/ba-p/1216032\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Keeping employees informed and engaged during difficult times</A>”</LI>\n</UL>\n</LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-news-web-part-on-a-sharepoint-page-c2dcee50-f5d7-434b-8cb9-a7feefd9f165\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">News</A> – publish daily and weekly news posts. They will appear here on the site and flow into everyone SharePoint start page where News from sites appear. &nbsp;</LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-twitter-web-part-15db6b3b-d167-41dd-9875-2af64b44d820\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter</A> – pull in feeds from public Twitter handles; the above example (per COVID-19) highlights <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/CDCgov\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@CDCgov</A> and I also suggest: <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/CDCemergency\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@CDCemergency</A> &amp; <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/WHO\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@WHO</A>.</LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/show-people-profiles-on-your-page-with-the-people-web-part-7e52c5f6-2d72-48fa-a9d3-d2750765fa05\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">People</A> – indicate the right people dedicated to the specific crisis. This is tied to Azure Active Directory and on-hover, visitors of the site will be able to see all their contact information.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>There, too, are web parts to <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-stream-web-part-b97fa87c-1337-4271-a059-17f0d2b26e8b\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">showcase videos</A>, <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-power-bi-web-part-32d8b85f-094d-4152-8e3b-df641ccf3968\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">BI dashboards</A>, <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-the-list-web-part-ef0a1b80-f8b3-443d-b04a-1e76c70b5537\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">lists</A> and more; see <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/using-web-parts-on-sharepoint-pages-336e8e92-3e2d-4298-ae01-d404bbe751e0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">all web parts in production</A> (scroll down to the “Available web parts” section of this help article).</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>You can adjust content at any time. You can rearrange where content is placed – aka, drag’n’drop web parts as you need. And know that everything will look great across web and mobile, resizing to the screen your people are using to get to the information.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT color=\"#339966\"><STRONG>Categorize top navigation with important pages, sites and more</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>Mega menus enable site navigation to be displayed at-a-glance. This increases the ease of use and exposure of more key content. You can put up to three levels of hierarchy, both enabling visual buckets of information and increases the likelihood of resources being discovered.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_005_top-nav.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175880i3C997160D42BC3FE/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_005_top-nav.jpg\" alt=\"SharePoint mega menus enable site navigation to be displayed at-a-glance.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">SharePoint mega menus enable site navigation to be displayed at-a-glance.</span></span></P>\n<P>Click <STRONG>Edit</STRONG> to the right of the default navigation elements to begin to add, adjust, delete and rearrange nav items. To&nbsp;<STRONG>Add</STRONG>&nbsp;a new header or sub-link, hover above header labels and select the&nbsp;<STRONG>+</STRONG>&nbsp;icon that will appear. To&nbsp;<STRONG>Edit</STRONG>,&nbsp;<STRONG>Move</STRONG>,&nbsp;<STRONG>Promote</STRONG>, and&nbsp;<STRONG>Remove&nbsp;</STRONG>select the ellipses next to the menu topic. <STRONG>Move</STRONG>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<STRONG>Promote</STRONG>&nbsp;headers and sub-links until they are in the desired position and select&nbsp;<STRONG>Save. </STRONG>Once you’ve arranged the hierarchy that works, click the upper right gear icon (site settings) and select&nbsp;<STRONG>Change the look</STRONG>. Select&nbsp;<STRONG>Mega menu</STRONG>&nbsp;and then select&nbsp;<STRONG>Save</STRONG>.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Make the top nav work for you. Make it your own. Learn more how to <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/create-a-mega-menu-in-hub-sites-d6768545-2391-4c66-9a8c-a85eb76b4cf5\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">create and adjust a mega menu in SharePoint communication sites</A>.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT color=\"#339966\"><STRONG>Last step: Share your site, aka, give the right permissions </STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>You set permissions to grant people access to the site. And you can broadly communicate to raise awareness about the new crisis management site.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Above the site, in the upper right, you’ll see a gear icon. Click it, select <STRONG>Site permissions</STRONG>, and then click <STRONG>Share site</STRONG>. Now you can type in broader security groups, Office 365 Groups or individuals (possibly others to help you manage the site; give them Edit permissions). For a site like this, it’s common to use the “<STRONG>Everyone</STRONG>” or “<STRONG>Everyone except external users</STRONG>” and ensure they are given <STRONG>Read</STRONG> permissions so that the most users in your organization can access the site in the right way once it’s ready; this then denotes them as <STRONG>Site visitors</STRONG>. Note: I typically uncheck the “Send email” option and rather use Outlook or Yammer to broadly communicate or Teams chat to raise awareness to my teams. Once you’ve decided on the right</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_006_share-site-permissions.jpg\" style=\"width: 752px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/175881i10C6AFA978EADFF2/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Build-Crisis-Management-site_006_share-site-permissions.jpg\" alt=\"Share the site to give permissions to all or select users and groups you wish to have access to the new site.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Share the site to give permissions to all or select users and groups you wish to have access to the new site.</span></span></P>\n<P>Learn more how to <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/manage-your-sharepoint-site-settings-8376034d-d0c7-446e-9178-6ab51c58df42#__bkmkmngsitepermissions\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">manage site permissions</A>.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>OK, on to additional materials out there to help best assess, learn and move forward.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>'How to' webinar </STRONG>[now on-demand; embedded below]</FONT></P>\n<P><SPAN><U>Title</U>:&nbsp;<STRONG>SharePoint: how to build a crisis management site</STRONG></SPAN></P>\n<P><U>Description</U><SPAN>: This 'how to' webinar walks you through how to establish a *crisis management* site using a SharePoint communication site in Office 365, both manually and with a pre-configured site design from the Microsoft Look Book.&nbsp;</SPAN></P>\n<P><SPAN><U>Date of recording</U>: March 27, 2020</SPAN></P>\n<P><SPAN><U>Webinar PowerPoint presentation</U>: <A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/gxcuf89792/attachments/gxcuf89792/SPBlog/4631/2/How-to-build-a-crisis-management-site_webinar_032720_mkashman.pdf\" target=\"_self\">PDF</A></SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><LI-VIDEO vid=\"https://youtu.be/GeQIAfpuhGs\" align=\"center\" size=\"large\" width=\"600\" height=\"338\" uploading=\"false\" thumbnail=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/GeQIAfpuhGs/hqdefault.jpg\" external=\"url\"></LI-VIDEO></P>\n<P>Two of the FAQs from the webinar that were not yet covered in this blog post:</P>\n<P><STRONG>Q: Is it possible to create multiple crisis managements sites within the same tenant?</STRONG></P>\n<P>A: Yes. You can create multiple crisis management type sites so long as you use different names for each site; aka, unique URLs.<STRONG><BR />Q: I want to create a portal for external people. Is that possible?</STRONG></P>\n<P>A: Yes. Make sure to work with your SharePoint administrator to help enable external sharing for the new site, inline with your external user governance plan before inviting guests.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>We also published <A href=\"https://aka.ms/TheIntrazone\" target=\"_self\">The Intrazone</A> podcast episode, \"<A href=\"http://intrazone.mpsn.libsynpro.com/crisis-management-and-remote-work\" target=\"_self\">Crisis management and remote work</A>\" :studio_microphone:</img> - embedded here&nbsp;highlighting three solutions - across Microsoft Teams, SharePoint and Power Apps - to help everyone stay briefed on the situation and any business impacts:</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><IFRAME src=\"https://html5-player.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/13671824/height/90/theme/custom/thumbnail/yes/direction/backward/render-playlist/no/custom-color/247bc1/\" width=\"100%\" height=\"90\" Microsoft Teams</A>\"\n<UL>\n<LI>5-page “<A href=\"https://download.microsoft.com/download/D/9/F/D9FE8B9E-22F5-47BF-A1AB-09539C41FCD0/Teams%20QS.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Quick start guide to Microsoft teams</A>” [PDF download]</LI>\n<LI>“<A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/video-what-is-microsoft-teams-422bf3aa-9ae8-46f1-83a2-e65720e1a34d\" target=\"_blank\" worker”</A> PDF infographic</LI>\n<LI>Additional <A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/gxcuf89792/attachments/gxcuf89792/DrivingAdoptionBlog/233/1/O365%20Day%20in%20the%20Life%20Preview.zip\" Apps]</LI>\n<LI>“<A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/yammer-blog/keeping-employees-informed-and-engaged-during-difficult-times/ba-p/1216032\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Keeping employees informed and engaged during difficult times</A>” [Yammer]</LI>\n<LI>Good <U>Twitter feeds</U> to broadly keep informed: <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/CDCemergency\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@CDCemergency</A>, <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/CDCgov\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@CDCgov</A>, &amp; <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/WHO\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@WHO</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Plus a few related <U>‘how to build SharePoint sites’ videos</U>:\n<UL>\n<LI>“<A href=\"https://myignite.techcommunity.microsoft.com/sessions/81510\" 10:31:28","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","title":"Revised end of support date for SharePoint Server 2010: April 13, 2021","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/revised-end-of-support-date-for-sharepoint-server-2010-april-13/ba-p/1285559","description":"<P>Microsoft’s top priority is the health and safety of our employees, customers, partners, and communities. In response to the COVID-19 crisis and an increase in customer requests, we have decided to revise support for SharePoint Server 2010 products and technologies. We recognize that discontinuing support for a product can be a big adjustment. We also know that some of you are in the process of upgrading to a newer version of SharePoint Server on-premises, or to the cloud with SharePoint in Microsoft 365.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>We will now be providing <A href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/help/14085/fixed-lifecycle-policy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Extended Support</A> for the following products until <STRONG>April 13, 2021</STRONG>, extending the original end of support date of October 13, 2020 by six months:&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>SharePoint Foundation 2010</LI>\n<LI>SharePoint Server 2010</LI>\n<LI>Project Server 2010</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>This includes extended support provided by our Customer Support Service (CSS) and monthly security updates.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-indent-padding-left-30px\"><STRONG>Note</STRONG> | Microsoft previously notified customers via the&nbsp;<A href=\"https://aka.ms/lifecycle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft Lifecycle website</A>&nbsp;and&nbsp;the&nbsp;<A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/extended-support-for-sharepoint-server-2010-ends-in-october-2020/ba-p/272628\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SharePoint Community blog</A>&nbsp;that the end of support was approaching. We will be updating these articles with details about the support extension and your upgrade and migration options.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>After the extended support period (April 13,&nbsp;2021), Microsoft will no longer provide technical support for problems that may occur including bug fixes for issues that are discovered and that may impact the stability and usability of the server, security fixes for vulnerabilities that are discovered and that may make the server vulnerable to security breaches, and time zone updates. Your installation of SharePoint Server 2010 will of course continue to run after April 13; however, due to potential end of support risks, we strongly recommend that you migrate from SharePoint Server 2010 as soon as possible. <A href=\"https://aka.ms/sharepointupdates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Monthly SharePoint Server updates</A>, including <A href=\"https://aka.ms/sharepointupdates#sharepoint-2010-update-history\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SharePoint Server 2010 monthly updates</A>, will continue during the new extension timeline.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-indent-padding-left-30px\"><STRONG>Note</STRONG> | If you are running SharePoint Server 2010 on Windows Server 2008 or Windows Server 2008 R2, you should <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/cloud-platform/windows-server-2008\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">consider options to obtain security updates for the underlying operating system</A>. If required, it is possible to <A href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/help/2724471/sharepoint-2010-support-for-windows-server-2012-and-windows-server-201\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">run SharePoint Server 2010 on Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2</A>. Microsoft suggests migration off SharePoint Server 2010 rather than updating the base Windows Server component.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><SPAN>Options to move forward</SPAN></FONT><BR /><STRONG>Migrate SharePoint 2010 products to Microsoft 365</STRONG></P>\n<P>Microsoft 365 is a cloud-based subscription service that brings together the best tools for the way people work today. By combining best-in-class apps with powerful cloud services, Microsoft 365 lets anyone create and collaborate anywhere on any device.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>You can use the SharePoint Migration Tool (<A href=\"https://aka.ms/SPMT\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SPMT</A>) to migrate from SharePoint Server 2010 to Microsoft 365. The SPMT supports migrations from SharePoint Server 2010 and SharePoint Foundation 2010, and this scenario will continue to be supported beyond the SharePoint 2010 end of support date.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P class=\"lia-indent-padding-left-30px\"><STRONG>Note</STRONG> | The SPMT does not support migration of Project Server 2010 Project Web Access sites to SharePoint at work or school in Office 365.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Upgrade to SharePoint Server 2019</STRONG></P>\n<P>If you need SharePoint Server to remain on-premises for the foreseeable future, you can upgrade to SharePoint Server 2019 to modernize your infrastructure and take advantage of the latest in content collaboration and portal technologies.&nbsp;Upgrading to the latest version of SharePoint Server on-premises is a multi-phased approach. You must first upgrade to SharePoint Server 2013 before you can upgrade to SharePoint Server 2016. For SharePoint Server 2019, you must first upgrade to SharePoint Server 2013 and then SharePoint Server 2016 before you can upgrade to SharePoint Server 2019.&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Below are helpful resources for navigating the upgrade process:</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepoint/upgrade-and-update/overview-of-the-upgrade-process-from-sharepoint-2010-to-sharepoint-2013\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Overview of the upgrade process from SharePoint 2010 to SharePoint 2013</A></LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/SharePoint/upgrade-and-update/upgrade-to-sharepoint-server-2016\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Upgrade to SharePoint Server 2016</A></LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/SharePoint/upgrade-and-update/upgrade-from-sharepoint2013-to-sharepointserver-2019\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">High level overview to upgrade from SharePoint 2013 to SharePoint Server 2019</A></LI>\n</UL>\n<P><STRONG>&nbsp;</STRONG></P>\n<P><STRONG>Migrating from Project Server 2010</STRONG></P>\n<P>For Project Server 2010, you have two options:</P>\n<P><BR /><U>Option 1</U>: <STRONG>Migrate to Project Online in Microsoft 365</STRONG> | Making the switch keeps your users current on the latest updates and features to work and collaborate on projects - no matter where they are located. Learn more about <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/office365/enterprise/project-server-2010-end-of-support#migrate-to-project-online\" target=\"_self\">migrating to Project Online</A>.</P>\n<P><BR /><U>Option 2</U>: <STRONG>Upgrade to Project Server 2019</STRONG> | If you need to remain on-premises, we suggest moving to Project Server 2019 to get the latest updates and performance enhancements. Upgrading is done in a phased approach, which is covered in the <A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/office365/enterprise/project-server-2010-end-of-support\" target=\"_self\">Project Server 2010 end of support roadmap</A>.</P>\n<P><BR />If you need to work with a partner, please visit <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/project/microsoft-project-partners\" target=\"_self\">Microsoft Project and Portfolio Management Partners</A> to find a partner in your country.<FONT size=\"4\"><BR /></FONT></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\">In summary</FONT></P>\n<P>We recommend moving to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 to receive the benefits of enhanced security, increased productivity and advantageous TCO.&nbsp; With Microsoft 365, you get out of the upgrade business. For customers who need to remain on-premises, we recommend upgrading to SharePoint Server 2019 to take advantage of the latest collaboration and productivity features.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\">Related information</FONT></P>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://aka.ms/lifecycle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><STRONG>Microsoft Lifecycle Policy</STRONG></A> – primary resource for Office 2010</A></LI>\n</UL>\n<H1>&nbsp;</H1>\n<H1><FONT size=\"5\">FAQs</FONT></H1>\n<P><STRONG>Q: Will Microsoft extend support for SharePoint 2010 beyond April 13, 2021?</STRONG></P>\n<P>A: Microsoft has no plans to extend support for SharePoint 2010 beyond April 13, 2021. This is a one-time extension due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Microsoft strongly recommends that customers complete their migrations and upgrades before end of support on April 13, 2021.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Q: Do I have to sign up for this support extension?</STRONG></P>\n<P>A: No, this support extension is automatically granted to all SharePoint Foundation 2010, SharePoint Server 2010, and Project Server 2010 customers.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Thanks, Mark Kashman - senior product manager and Troy Starr - senior program manager</P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 16 Apr 2020 22:08:12 +0000","feedId":13333,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"29906757116526bc91acc08ce2184a64","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"Mark Kashman","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598322688825},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","title":"Share videos and engage with an audience using Microsoft Stream and SharePoint","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/share-videos-and-engage-with-an-audience-using-microsoft-stream/ba-p/1292811","description":"<P>Share educational videos with your class or highlights from meeting recordings with your coworkers remotely by adding the <A href=\"https://support.office.com/en-us/article/use-the-stream-web-part-b97fa87c-1337-4271-a059-17f0d2b26e8b\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft Stream web part to your SharePoint site</A>. 86","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/microsoft-365-amp-sharepoint-pnp-weekly-episode-86/ba-p/1456070","description":"<P><span Mastykarz</A><SPAN>&nbsp;(Rencore),&nbsp;are joined by this week are 2 members of the PnP Team and MVPs –</SPAN><WBR /><SPAN>&nbsp;</SPAN><A href=\"https://twitter.com/PaoloPia\" Principal Consultant with Catapult Systems, Los Angeles, US. </SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>The discussion topic for the day: How does the PnP team get so much done? It seems like we do a lot because our work in done in the open.&nbsp; Yes, sharing with the PnP Community is indeed a conscious priority after family.&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>Discussion takeaways: Caring requires contributors to be consistent, to communicate, to be good time managers, to not be self-critical or perfectionists, to be willing to distribute the load, and to find ways to share in a way that benefits your employer, your client and your community at the same time.&nbsp;&nbsp; </SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>“<EM>Shipped is better than perfect</EM>”, and any size contribution is a welcome contribution. Sharing is caring. Additionally, in this episode, 15 recently released articles from Microsoft and the PnP Community are highlighted.</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>As always, if you need help on an issue, want to share a discovery, or just want to say: “<EM>Job well done</EM>”, please reach out to Vesa, to Waldek or to your PnP Community.</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>This episode was recorded on Monday, June 8, 2020</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><SPAN><A href=\"https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/blogs/microsoft-365-sharepoint-pnp-weekly-episode-86/\" target=\"_self\">Microsoft 365 SharePoint PnP Weekly – Episode 86</A></SPAN></LI>\n</UL>\n<P><SPAN>Did we miss your article? Project reprioritization –<WBR /><SPAN>&nbsp;</SPAN>smaller projects are leading to larger projects, cloud adoption is accelerating, Microsoft Teams usage is high and driving SharePoint and wider<SPAN>&nbsp;</SPAN><SPAN class=\"brand\">Microsoft 365</SPAN><SPAN>&nbsp;</SPAN>and Azure Platform adoption, and development focus is on extending the platform rather than waiting on changes to the platform.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>While citizen development empowers, it also necessitates the need for governance, change management and education. Fortunately, internal “ambassador” programs are emerging as a means to communicate change.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><SPAN>This episode was recorded on Monday, May 4, 2020.</SPAN></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/blogs/microsoft-365-sharepoint-pnp-weekly-episode-82/\" target=\"_self\" rel=\"noreferrer\">Microsoft 365 &amp; SharePoint PnP Weekly – Episode 82</A></LI>\n</UL>\n<P><SPAN>Did we miss your article? various locations where you can create and use lists - from the Lists app in Microsoft 365, from within Teams and SharePoint - all with a consistent user experience for creating and using lists.\n</P> And this part is all about the customer experience and use cases.\n</P> \n<P>\n &nbsp;\n</P> \n<P>\n In this #YearOfYammer – pt.2, Chris and I talk to \n <A href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelholste/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\n  Michael Holste\n </A> and \n <A href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/angusflorance/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">\n  Angus Florance\n </A> – both from Yammer marketing. We dive into what customers are doing with Yammer to bolster their intelligent intranet, focused on best practices for adoption and how it fits into their broader intranet strategy. intranet (aka.ms/TheIntrazone).</span></span>\n</P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Thu, 16 Jan 2020 18:35:58 +0000","feedId":13333,"bgimg":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/165680i287E2689D540375B/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999","linkMd5":"bb47583ce5644b3575cbc179f4b53caa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn33@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-31-32-560_90390f2abfc77c40.webp","destWidth":998,"destHeight":290,"sourceBytes":58977,"destBytes":43124,"author":"Mark Kashman","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/165680i287E2689D540375B/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn33@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-31-32-560_90390f2abfc77c40.webp","https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/165685iC6EE1E3B35358DD7/image-size/medium?v=1.0&px=400":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn41@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-31-43-245_e6993ea5392b378d.webp","https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/165679iBD9210B5929D096C/image-size/medium?v=1.0&px=400":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn77@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-31-44-992_83d19e37817aa752.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598322688838},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","title":"New SharePoint feature: Multilingual publishing for pages and news posts","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/new-sharepoint-feature-multilingual-publishing-for-pages-and/ba-p/1432445","description":"<P>With organizations around the world enabling remote work for their teams, it is essential now, more than ever, to ensure that information on your intranet is readily available to your users. Using communication sites in SharePoint for Microsoft 365, you can now create a flexible, intelligent intranet in multiple languages!</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>The multilingual publishing feature for SharePoint communication sites, now rolled out worldwide, enables you to create and translate pages, set translator roles, and get email alerts when pages are ready to be translated, updated, and published. All of this comes on top of the rich and flexible pages and news creation experience in SharePoint. Everything is built to give the user the best experience possible. Let's jump in to see how multilingual publishing for modern SharePoint works. Here is a quick overview video:</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><IFRAME src=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/videoplayer/embed/RE4wwp3\" width=\"95%\" height=\"600px\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\"></IFRAME></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>So how does it work?</STRONG></P>\n<P>Once a communication site has been created in the default language, the site owner can enable the multilingual publishing feature and choose the additional languages to support on that site.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Once the feature has been enabled and languages added, the site owner can assign individual users, security groups, and Office 365 groups as <EM>translators</EM> for each of the languages.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"translator.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195858iF75DA98411209930/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"translator.png\" alt=\"translator.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Then, page authors can make copies of pages created in the default language. The content in the copies can then be manually translated by the translator who’d be notified when there is a new default language page requiring translation or when an existing default language page is updated. When translations are published the author of the default language will be notified as well. Published translation pages are automatically shown in the users’ language, including in the News web part and the Highlighted content web part.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"multilanguage.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195859iAACA744674432380/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"multilanguage.png\" alt=\"multilanguage.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>When<A href=\"https://support.office.com/en-us/article/approval-flow-for-modern-pages-a8b2e689-d4a1-4639-8028-333c0ece30d9\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> page approvals</A> are turned on, the default language pages and the translation pages must be approved and published before the translation pages are available to everyone who has access to the page. This extra layer of review and approval can help ensure that incorrect information is not published.</P>\n<P><BR />Site navigation, hub navigation, site name and site footer can also be translated. The content there is first created in the site default language and then translators can log in and update navigation, site name etc. in their preferred language. Users will automatically see pages and news in their preferred language if its published. If not available, and they would like to view pages in other available languages, they will be able to do so using the dropdown menu in the top right corner of the page.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"Multilingual.png\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195860iAF2050D8DC677B58/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"Multilingual.png\" alt=\"Multilingual.png\" /></span></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Communication between teams, managers and everyone in between is one of the most important things an organization can facilitate at this time. With many teams spread all over the globe, Microsoft is proud to be able to provide a tool built into modern SharePoint that helps to ensure your information is easily delivered to your team. Get more information, exact steps and troubleshooting tips in our article: <A href=\"https://support.office.com/en-us/article/create-multilingual-communication-sites-pages-and-news-2bb7d610-5453-41c6-a0e8-6f40b3ed750c?ui=en-US&amp;rs=en-US&amp;ad=US\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Create multilingual communication sites, pages, and news</A>.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>You can also view a video demo of the feature <A href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V3mtnoIlFEY\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here</A> or hear more about the builiding of the feature in this <A href=\"http://intrazone.mpsn.libsynpro.com/sharepoint-roadmap-pitstop-march-2020\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Intrazone podcast.</A></P>","descriptionType":"text/html","publishedDate":"Tue, 02 Jun 2020 16:22:08 +0000","feedId":13333,"bgimg":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195858iF75DA98411209930/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999","linkMd5":"873821ac333e8a7762e7fe80eef53481","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn77@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-31-31-283_27b30fb25d64ca3b.webp","destWidth":999,"destHeight":609,"sourceBytes":117510,"destBytes":24560,"author":"DC Padur","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195858iF75DA98411209930/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn77@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-31-31-283_27b30fb25d64ca3b.webp","https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195859iAACA744674432380/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn97@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-31-38-739_891dc1f45a5892fc.webp","https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195860iAF2050D8DC677B58/image-size/large?v=1.0&px=999":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn61@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-31-45-183_ae65a574c30718b7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598322688817},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:31:28","title":"SharePoint Roadmap Pitstop: May 2020","link":"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/sharepoint-roadmap-pitstop-may-2020/ba-p/1431041","description":"<P>May 2020 brought the Save for later web part, updated Yammer Conversations web part, scheduling pages and news, an extended site footer, ease of migration into Microsoft Teams, lists flexibility and more. Details &amp; screenshots below, including the audible companion: <STRONG>Intrazone Roadmap Pitstop: May 2020</STRONG> podcast episode – all to help answer, \"What's rolling out now for SharePoint and related technologies into Microsoft 365?\"</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><IFRAME src=\"https://html5-player.libsyn.com/embed/episode/id/14632217/height/90/theme/custom/thumbnail/yes/direction/backward/render-playlist/no/custom-color/247bc1/\" width=\"100%\" height=\"90\" scrolling=\"no\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\" webkitallowfullscreen=\"webkitallowfullscreen\" style=\"border: none;\" mozallowfullscreen=\"mozallowfullscreen\" oallowfullscreen=\"\" msallowfullscreen=\"\"></IFRAME></P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>In the podcast episode, I interview <STRONG>Simon Bourdages </STRONG>(<A href=\"https://www.linkedin.com/in/simonbourdages/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">LinkedIn</A> | <A href=\"https://twitter.com/bourdages_s\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter</A>), senior program manager at Microsoft who works on content migration technology. Simon and I talk about the broader migration portfolio and capabilities offered by Microsoft and our partners – with a highlight on how you can bring content in from on-premises directly into Microsoft Teams.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_001_Simon-Bourdages.jpg\" style=\"width: 400px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195733i9F82C13576F449EE/image-size/medium?v=1.0&amp;px=400\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_001_Simon-Bourdages.jpg\" alt=\"Simon Bourdages, senior program manager (SharePoint/Microsoft) [Intrazone guest]\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Simon Bourdages, senior program manager (SharePoint/Microsoft) [Intrazone guest]</span></span></P>\n<P>All features listed below began rolling out to Targeted Release customers in Microsoft 365 as of May 2020 (possibly early June 2020).</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>Inform and engage with dynamic employee experiences</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>Build your intelligent intranet on SharePoint in Microsoft 365 and get the benefits of investing in business outcomes – reducing IT and development costs, increasing business speed and agility, and up-leveling the dynamic, personalized and welcoming nature of your intranet.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>SharePoint home sites are LIVE - aka, available to everyone.</STRONG></P>\n<P>A home site is the top landing page for your organization’s intelligent intranet. With a simple PowerShell cmdlet, you deem a communication site the home site. It will then be a highly visible and unique entry point, including the new home button in the SharePoint mobile app.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_002_SP-home-sites_pt1.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195734i04A3D121FAC215F3/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_002_SP-home-sites_pt1.jpg\" alt=\"A SharePoint home site is a communication site that is designed and designated to serve as the top portal in your organization.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">A SharePoint home site is a communication site that is designed and designated to serve as the top portal in your organization.</span></span></P>\n<P>In addition, your home site will be automatically setup to be an&nbsp;<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepoint/organization-news-site\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">organizational news site</A>&nbsp;and have organization-wide search pre-configured.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_003_SP-home-sites_pt2_mobile.jpg\" style=\"width: 258px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195735i430020BC2ECD8178/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_003_SP-home-sites_pt2_mobile.jpg\" alt=\"Once your SharePoint home site is set up, the home button in the SharePoint mobile app automatically takes each user to it.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Once your SharePoint home site is set up, the home button in the SharePoint mobile app automatically takes each user to it.</span></span></P>\n<P>So, <STRONG>Set-SPOHomeSite -HomeSiteUrl &lt;siteUrl&gt;</STRONG> today.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Learn more about&nbsp;<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/SharePoint/home-site\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">setting up a home site</A>.</LI>\n<LI>If you would like to enable a home site on a new or existing SharePoint communication site, run this PowerShell command in the latest version of the&nbsp;<A href=\"https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/introduction-to-the-sharepoint-online-management-shell-c16941c3-19b4-4710-8056-34c034493429\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SharePoint Online Management Shell</A>: Set-SPOHomeSite -HomeSiteUrl</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=26842\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 26842</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Saved for later web part is now available for modern pages</STRONG></P>\n<P>We’re adding a new way for each user to see the content they’ve saved when they view your page. There are a few places Microsoft uses the Saved for later web part, and now you can use it where it makes sense.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_004_Save-for-later-web-part.jpg\" style=\"width: 400px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195736i45A0A82220989366/image-size/medium?v=1.0&amp;px=400\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_004_Save-for-later-web-part.jpg\" alt=\"The Saved for layer web part shows each user the content they’ve saved when they view your page.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">The Saved for layer web part shows each user the content they’ve saved when they view your page.</span></span></P>\n<P>Page authors determine the source of Saved items that will show up: <EM>All saved items</EM> (to show all of the page viewer's items across SharePoint) or<EM> Saved items from this site</EM> (to show all of the user's saved items from the site on which the page is located).</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Roadmap&nbsp;<A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;featureid=57810\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 57810</A></LI>\n<LI>Learn more how to <A href=\"https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2121309\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">use the Saved for later web part</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P><STRONG>The Yammer Conversations web part gets a nice update</STRONG></P>\n<P>You'll now see the new Yammer experience embedded into SharePoint pages. You'll be able to create any type of Yammer post directly in SharePoint, start a conversation in any community, upload images and files into Yammer conversations - all directly from SharePoint.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_005_Yammer-Conversations-web-part.jpg\" style=\"width: 789px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195738iC3E21245A420D173/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_005_Yammer-Conversations-web-part.jpg\" alt=\"The Yammer Conversations web part, shown here on a SharePoint home site, enables two-way employee engagement across your intelligent intranet.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">The Yammer Conversations web part, shown here on a SharePoint home site, enables two-way employee engagement across your intelligent intranet.</span></span></P>\n<P>It is the Year of Yammer and that includes updating the bi-directional conversation value you can build into your site and portal experiences.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>FYI | we've got a two-part discussion on The Intrazone with our Yammer leads covering all the new #YearOfYammer innovation. <A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/year-of-yammer-pt-1-vision-and-strategy-the-intrazone-podcast/ba-p/1418338\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Part 1</A> is out already, and part 2 is coming next week.</LI>\n<LI>Learn more how to <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/use-a-yammer-web-part-in-sharepoint-online-a53cfa0c-3d09-42c8-a286-1038a81c59da#conversations\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">use a Yammer Conversations web part in SharePoint</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap IDs <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=63385\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">63385</A>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=63530\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">63530</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Scheduling pages and news posts</STRONG></P>\n<P>We’re introducing the ability for SharePoint page authors to schedule pages and news posts for publication at a future date and time. SharePoint site owners will have the option to enable scheduling on their sites; note: it is disabled by default.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_006_Schedule-pages.jpg\" style=\"width: 347px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195739iF40365B2EBAD5858/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_006_Schedule-pages.jpg\" alt=\"Schedule pages and news posts for publication at a future date and time.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Schedule pages and news posts for publication at a future date and time.</span></span></P>\n<P>When scheduling is enabled, <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/schedule-a-sharepoint-page-or-news-post-to-go-live-at-a-specific-time-4b81873c-9bbc-4307-b7ea-7b6662ff1af2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">page authors will be able to set a date and time</A> for their pages and news posts to publish. It's that easy. Plan ahead, and rest easy knowing pages and news can go live on schedule.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>If you need to&nbsp;edit a scheduled page to&nbsp;update the content or change the scheduled time and date, you must schedule the page again by selecting&nbsp;<STRONG>Schedule</STRONG>. If you don't do this,&nbsp;the page will not publish at any time. You can also edit a page and remove scheduling. In this case, you can publish the page immediately by selecting either&nbsp;<STRONG>Publish</STRONG>,&nbsp;<STRONG>Post news</STRONG>,&nbsp;<STRONG>Republish</STRONG>&nbsp;or&nbsp;<STRONG>Update news</STRONG>.&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Learn more about&nbsp;<A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/schedule-a-sharepoint-page-or-news-post-to-go-live-at-a-specific-time-4b81873c-9bbc-4307-b7ea-7b6662ff1af2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">scheduling a SharePoint page or news</A>&nbsp;post to go live at a specific time.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=62892\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 62892</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Pre-publish overview experience for SharePoint pages and news</STRONG></P>\n<P>When page authors select an action, such as Publish, Republish, Post news, Update news, Schedule, or Submit for approval, the <STRONG>pre-publish panel</STRONG> appears on the right. Here you'll get an overview of the site name, a thumbnail preview, and information about what happens when you publish.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_007_pre-publish-pages.jpg\" style=\"width: 400px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195740i366E444F0E663A14/image-size/medium?v=1.0&amp;px=400\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_007_pre-publish-pages.jpg\" alt=\"Get actionable insights before you publish your page or news article in SharePoint.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Get actionable insights before you publish your page or news article in SharePoint.</span></span></P>\n<P>The pre-publish panel also has a link to the Page details pane so authors can make changes if needed. Pre-visualization is the key to pre-publishing success.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/management-and-lifecycle-of-a-sharepoint-modern-page-3410a04c-3ca4-4a4c-b867-33ab5c8bdcf3\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Learn more</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=63257\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 63257</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Extended Site Footer</STRONG></P>\n<P>The site footer in modern communication sites will now include a new layout option - \"Extended\" - which means you can show more content and links at the bottom of your communication pages. You can also select a distinct background color to distinguish it from the other sections above.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_008_extended-site-footer.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195741iD69C73940CC79252/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_008_extended-site-footer.jpg\" alt=\"You can now choose an Extended layout for the communication site page footer.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">You can now choose an Extended layout for the communication site page footer.</span></span></P>\n<P><U>Note</U>: The site footer feature is only available on communication site <EM>site pages</EM>. They are not available for default list pages or library pages. You can add one level of up to eight links or labels.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Learn <A href=\"https://support.office.com/article/Change-the-look-of-your-SharePoint-site-06bbadc3-6b04-4a60-9d14-894f6a170818\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">more</A>. For details about adding or editing links and labels, see&nbsp;<A href=\"https://support.office.com/en-us/article/customize-the-navigation-on-your-sharepoint-site-3cd61ae7-a9ed-4e1e-bf6d-4655f0bf25ca\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Customize the navigation on your SharePoint site</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=61063\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 61063</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>Teamwork updates across SharePoint team sites, OneDrive and Microsoft Teams</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>Microsoft 365 is designed to be a universal toolkit for teamwork – to give you the right tools for the right task, along with common services to help you seamlessly work across applications. SharePoint is the intelligent content service that powers teamwork – to better collaborate on proposals, projects, and campaigns throughout your organization – with integration across Microsoft Teams, OneDrive, Yammer, Stream, Planner and much more.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Microsoft Lists (first public disclosure)</STRONG></P>\n<P><A href=\"https://aka.ms/MSLists/blog\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft Lists</A> is an evolution of SharePoint lists, expanding on the ability to support a multitude of work management scenarios so you can stay on top of what matters most to your team - like tracking issues, asset management, managing events, inventory tracking and more using customizable views and smart rules to keep everyone in sync.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Lists compliment the productivity portfolio alongside task management apps like Planner, file management, group calendars, chats, meetings, note taking - all the tools to best support sharing and working together.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_009_MSLists-animation.gif\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195742i93FC0D8304980F28/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_009_MSLists-animation.gif\" alt=\"Microsoft Lists is a Microsoft 365 app that helps you track information and organize work. List are simple, smart and flexible, so you can stay on top of what matters most to your team.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Microsoft Lists is a Microsoft 365 app that helps you track information and organize work. List are simple, smart and flexible, so you can stay on top of what matters most to your team.</span></span></P>\n<P>Microsoft published 10 new items to the Microsoft 365 public roadmap to indicate all everything, like the new Lists home page, ready-made templates, customizable forms, rules, comments, creating lists in Microsoft Teams, the Lists mobile app, and more; most will land this summer in Microsoft 365, and we know in advance that the Lists mobile app will come for iOS&nbsp; later in the year.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>We're excited to signal the evolution of SharePoint lists, aka Microsoft Lists coming soon.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Last, a Lists Intrazone FYI, we published a <A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/make-a-list-and-check-it-twice-the-intrazone-podcast-all-about/ba-p/1400928\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">unique episode all about Microsoft Lists</A> this month, chatting with our Lists engineering leads, Miceile Barrett and Lincoln DeMaris - a great, informative discussion.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Learn more about <A href=\"https://aka.ms/MSLists\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft Lists (resource center)</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap IDs, x10: <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64160\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64160</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64161\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64161</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64162\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64162</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64163\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64163</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64164\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64164</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64165\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64165</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64166\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64166</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64167\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64167</A>, <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64168\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64168</A> and <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64169\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64169</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Conditionally show or hide columns in a SharePoint list or library form</STRONG></P>\n<P>This allows people to show or hide columns in a SharePoint list or library form based on another column's value by specifying a formula. The formula is made up of equations that perform conditional checks on certain values.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_010_conditional-show-hide-list-forms.jpg\" style=\"width: 880px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195743i15CB52D0089F31E4/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_010_conditional-show-hide-list-forms.jpg\" alt=\"You can show or hide columns in a list form based on another column's value by specifying a formula that are equations performing conditional checks on values in a SharePoint list or library.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">You can show or hide columns in a list form based on another column's value by specifying a formula that are equations performing conditional checks on values in a SharePoint list or library.</span></span></P>\n<P>For example, you could hide a number column from view if the row number is equal to or less than a specific number - thus only showing data that is over a certain desired threshold to call to attention.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>To&nbsp;learn&nbsp;more about this feature,&nbsp;and how to work with conditional formulas, see&nbsp;&nbsp;<A href=\"https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2125114\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Show or hide columns in a list or library form</A>.&nbsp;</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap ID: <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=63518\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">63518</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Create a list from a Microsoft Excel table</STRONG></P>\n<P>This is a new way to create a list, saving you time while putting the data in a location that opens up new collaborative scenarios. To create a list from Excel, you select a table of data from the Excel file.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_011_Creat-list-from-Excel.gif\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195744iFB709932FA3E3C78/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_011_Creat-list-from-Excel.gif\" alt=\"When you create a list from Microsoft Excel, you map table data to a new list – adjusting column types before you click Create.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">When you create a list from Microsoft Excel, you map table data to a new list – adjusting column types before you click Create.</span></span></P>\n<P>Before importing, you can change the column types, and all your table data will be copied in as new rows of data in the new list. You can then assign and adjust data types to other columns, enhance visuals by designing row and column formatting, use conditional rules to make the list data intuitive and helpful, set reminders and build productivity apps with Power Automate (for custom flows) and Power Apps (for custom forms); your list then becomes the foundational data store.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>One important note to close out on lists from Excel… you can analyze SharePoint list items at any time back in Excel. Excel creates a table with a one-way data connection; you can click <EM>Refresh All</EM> to get the latest from the list. Note: Changes made to the Excel table will not be sent back to the SharePoint list.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/create-a-list-from-microsoft-excel/ba-p/1422192\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Learn more</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap ID: <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=61013\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">61013</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>SharePoint Migration Tool makes is easy to bring content from on-prem directly into Microsoft Teams</STRONG></P>\n<P>You define your source where the files will move from, and then select a team you own or have access to determine the channel you want to use as the destination.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_012_SPMT-plus-Teams.jpg\" style=\"width: 848px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195745i57A316EA14772DFB/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_012_SPMT-plus-Teams.jpg\" alt=\"Welcome to the SharePoint Migration Tool (SPMT) – migrate file shares or Sharepoint Server sites to SharePoint, OneDrive, and Teams – all in Microsoft 365.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Welcome to the SharePoint Migration Tool (SPMT) – migrate file shares or Sharepoint Server sites to SharePoint, OneDrive, and Teams – all in Microsoft 365.</span></span></P>\n<P>The real value beyond clicking the magic <EM>GO</EM> button is what you can now do with that set of files for greater co-authoring, working in the browser with Office for the web, syncing files for offline use, improved thumbnail previews, and more - plus the unique benefit of having a chat experience side-by-side with your content.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Learn more:&nbsp;<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepointmigration/new-and-improved-features-in-the-sharepoint-migration-tool\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Release notes for the SharePoint Migration Tool (SPMT)</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepointmigration/sharepoint-online-and-onedrive-migration-speed\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Performance guidance</A></LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepointmigration/fileshare-to-odsp-migration-guide\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">File share to Microsoft 365 guidance</A></LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepointmigration/sp-teams-sites-migration-guide\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Migrating from SharePoint Server on-premises guidance</A></LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/sharepointmigration/mover-box-to-o365\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Migrate from Box into Microsoft 365 guidance</A></LI>\n</UL>\n<UL>\n<LI>Message center post: <A href=\"https://admin.microsoft.com/Adminportal/Home?source=applauncher#MessageCenter?id=MC213376\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">MC213376</A>.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>Related technology</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P><STRONG>Microsoft Stream to record your screen</STRONG></P>\n<P>Video creators can record any window or screen, add mic or system audio, and include webcam video. There is no need to download any additional software; the tool is web based and works with latest version of Edge or Chrome.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_013_Stream-screen-record.jpg\" style=\"width: 999px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195746iE0B240EFC5CB4E71/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_013_Stream-screen-record.jpg\" alt=\"Using Microsoft Stream, you can create short screen recordings of up to 15 minutes, including your camera and microphone, without any additional software.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Using Microsoft Stream, you can create short screen recordings of up to 15 minutes, including your camera and microphone, without any additional software.</span></span></P>\n<P>Show, don’t tell - but please, tell everyone they have a new tool to share an issue they're seeing, to demonstrate a new app or tool, or to build out training materials - all stream'lined within Microsoft 365.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Find information about system compatibility, feature specifics and management here:&nbsp;<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/stream/portal-create-screen-recording\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Create a screen recording</A> and related <A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-stream-blog/screen-recording-for-training-videos-and-communications-with/ba-p/1362099\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">blog</A>.</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap&nbsp;<A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;featureid=25687\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 25687 </A></LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><STRONG>Microsoft 365 Records Management is now generally available</STRONG></P>\n<P>Records managers, start your record declarations engines! You can now utilize the Records Management solution to help your organization meet your regulatory record-keeping obligations through discovering, classifying, labeling, retaining, and defensibly deleting content across your Microsoft 365 tenant - inclusive of third-party data.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper lia-image-align-inline\" image-alt=\"IZRP-May.2020_014_RecordsCenter.jpg\" style=\"width: 800px;\"><img src=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/image/serverpage/image-id/195747iDE31A03B2486DEEF/image-size/large?v=1.0&amp;px=999\" title=\"IZRP-May.2020_014_RecordsCenter.jpg\" alt=\"Records Management solution to help meet your legal, business and regulatory recordkeeping obligations. Create retention labels and author policies from within the Microsoft 365 compliance center.\" /><span class=\"lia-inline-image-caption\" onclick=\"event.preventDefault();\">Records Management solution to help meet your legal, business and regulatory recordkeeping obligations. Create retention labels and author policies from within the Microsoft 365 compliance center.</span></span></P>\n<P>This new solution is the recommended and forward-looking approach to managing records in Microsoft 365 -&nbsp; available within the Microsoft 365 Compliance Center.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Learn more\n<UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/security-privacy-and-compliance/announcing-general-availability-of-records-management/ba-p/1347879\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Announcing general availability of Records Management</A></LI>\n<LI><A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/compliance/records-management\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Records Management in Microsoft 365</A></LI>\n</UL>\n</LI>\n<LI>Roadmap <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=63058\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ID: 63058</A></LI>\n</UL>\n<P><STRONG>&nbsp;</STRONG></P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>June 2020 teasers</STRONG></FONT></P>\n<P>Psst, still here? Still scrolling the page looking for the rolled out goodness? If so, here’s a few teasers of what’s to come to production next month…</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<UL>\n<LI>Teaser #1: <STRONG>SharePoint default site theme changing from blue to tea</STRONG>l [Roadmap ID: <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=60592\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">60592</A>]&nbsp;</LI>\n<LI>Teaser #2: <STRONG>Lists Quick Edit page size is expanding from 30 items to 100 </STRONG>[Roadmap ID: <A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?filters=&amp;searchterms=64231\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">64231</A>]</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>… shhh, tell everyone.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><FONT size=\"5\"><STRONG>Helpful, ongoing change management resources </STRONG></FONT></P>\n<UL>\n<LI>\"<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/office365/admin/manage/stay-on-top-of-updates\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Stay on top of Office 365 changes</A>\"</LI>\n<LI>\"<A href=\"https://docs.microsoft.com/office365/admin/manage/message-center\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Message center in Office 365</A>\"</LI>\n<UL>\n<LI>Install the <A href=\"https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=627216\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Office 365 admin app</A>; view Message Center posts and stay current with push notifications.</LI>\n</UL>\n<LI><A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Microsoft 365 public roadmap</A> <SPAN>+ pre-filtered URL for </SPAN><A href=\"https://www.microsoft.com/microsoft-365/roadmap?ms.url=roadmap&amp;rtc=1&amp;filters=Rolling%20Out%2CLaunched%2CIn%20Development%2CYammer%2CSharePoint%2CMicrosoft%20Stream%2COneDrive%20for%20Business\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SharePoint, OneDrive, Yammer and Stream roadmap items</A><SPAN>.</SPAN></LI>\n</UL>\n<UL>\n<LI><STRONG>SharePoint</STRONG> <A href=\"https://www.facebook.com/MSSharePoint\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Facebook</A> | <A href=\"https://twitter.com/SharePoint\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter</A> | <A href=\"http://office.com/sharepoint/community\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">SharePoint Community Blog</A> | <A href=\"https://sharepoint.uservoice.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">UserVoice</A></LI>\n<LI><STRONG>OneDrive</STRONG> <A href=\"https://www.facebook.com/OneDrive\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Facebook</A> | <A href=\"https://www.twitter.com/onedrive\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Twitter</A> | <A href=\"https://aka.ms/SharePoint/blog\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">OneDrive Community Blog</A> | <A href=\"https://onedrive.uservoice.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">UserVoice</A></LI>\n</UL>\n<UL>\n<LI>Follow me to catch <STRONG>news and interesting SharePoint things</STRONG>: <A href=\"https://twitter.com/mkashman\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">@mkashman</A>; warning, occasional bad puns may fly in a tweet or two here and there.</LI>\n</UL>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Thanks for tuning in and/or reading this episode/blog of the <STRONG>Intrazone Roadmap Pitstop – May 2020 </STRONG>(<A href=\"https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/microsoft-sharepoint-blog/sharepoint-roadmap-pitstop-may-2020/ba-p/1431041\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">blog</A>/<A href=\"http://intrazone.mpsn.libsynpro.com/sharepoint-roadmap-pitstop-may-2020\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">podcast</A>). We’re open to your feedback in comments below to hear how both the Roadmap Pitstop podcast episodes and blogs can be improved over time.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Engage with us. Ask questions. Push us where you want and need to get the best information and insights. We're here to put both our and your best change management foot forward.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Stay safe out there on the road’map, and thanks for listening and reading.</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P>Cheers and thanks,</P>\n<P>Mark “from the month of May” Kashman – senior product manager (SharePoint/Lists| Microsoft)</P>\n<P>&nbsp;</P>\n<P><span class=\"lia-inline-image-display-wrapper
